title: Table
summary: A table displays structured data for overview and comparison.

anatomyitems.text: Header row - Defines and labels each column
Rows - Each row represents a single item or record.
Cells - Contain values aligned to the column type.

overview.section-content:
The table component is used to display structured data in rows and columns. It supports overview, comparison and data-driven tasks where users need to scan or interact with multiple items.  
Tables should represent meaningful data relationships and must not be used for layout or visual alignment.

overview.title: When to use
overview.section-content:
*   You have multiple items that share the same set of attributes  (for example users, transactions, configurations or accounts).
    
*   Users need to compare values across items, such as dates, statuses or amounts.
    
*   The content is data-centric, rather than descriptive or narrative.
    
*   Users are expected to scan, sort, filter or act on the data.
    
*   The information has a clear and consistent structure, where each column represents the same type of data across all rows.

overview.title: When not to use
overview.section-content:
*   Items are standalone and do not share a common structure.
    
*   Content is primarily descriptive, narrative or instructional.
    
*   You are presenting steps, guidelines, explanations or recommendations.
    
*   The dataset is small and comparison does not add value.
    
*   A simpler structure provides better readability and accessibility.
    

### Consider alternatives

*   **Bulleted lists** - For independent items without comparable attributes.
    
*   **Numbered lists** - When order or sequence matters.
    
*   **Text or other components** - When content is explanatory or not data-driven.

overview.title: Guidelines
overview.section-content:
*   Always include a header row.
    
*   Use clear and descriptive column labels.
    
*   Keep the structure predictable and consistent.
    
*   Avoid complex or merged headers where possible.
    
*   Text content should be left-aligned for readability.
    
*   Numeric values should be right-aligned, preferably aligned by decimal, to support comparison.
    
*   Avoid repeating information in table cells when it can be communicated through the column header. Reducing repetition improves scannability and overall clarity.

dolist.text: Use tables for overview and comparison.

dontlist.text: Place long descriptive text inside cells.
Mix unrelated data types in the same column.
Add interaction without a clear user need.

ux-text.title: Writing UX text for table
ux-text.section-content: Tables should make information easy to scan, compare and understand at a glance. Good table writing focuses on clarity, consistency and space efficiency.

columns.title: Keep the column label short and clear
columns.content: Use short labels and values. Aim for one or two words in each cell whenever possible. Avoid unnecessary words or repetition. If more explanation is needed, use tooltips.

columns.title: Units and symbols
columns.content: Do not repeat units or symbols, such as %, kr or EUR, in every cell if the entire column uses the same unit. Instead, include the unit or symbol in the column heading.

columns.title: Be careful with capital letters
columns.content:
Use sentence case in headings and labels. Only capitalise:

*   the first word
    
*   proper names
    
*   abbreviations.

columns.title: Handle empty values clearly
columns.content: Don’t leave cells blank. Use an en dash (–) to show that a value is missing or not applicable.

columns.title: Align content for readability
columns.content: Left-align text and right-align numbers to make scanning easier.

columns.title: Error messages or other messages in tables
columns.content:
Sometimes, error handling is required in tables. Keep messages concise, as space is often limited.

*   Short messages can appear within a table column.
    
*   Longer messages should appear in a separate row beneath the relevant data.
    
*   Messages may include a link to a help page or another relevant page.  
    Messages displayed below should be limited to two rows, including any links.
    

Example: If a mutual fund has been removed from our range, but the customer has not yet updated their default fund distribution, an error message will appear when they try to buy funds according to that distribution or change it.

**Example message:**

It is no longer possible to trade in this fund. Please change your fund distribution.
